name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can define resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current
items.what: Resistance (R) equals potential difference (V) divided by current (I). The unit of resistance is the ohm (Î©), where 1 Î© = 1 V/A.
items.why: Resistance quantifies how much a component opposes current flow, which is essential information for selecting components and designing circuits.
items.example: A light bulb with 12 V across it and 0.5 A flowing through it has resistance R = V/I = 12/0.5 = 24 Î©. This tells us the bulb opposes current flow moderately.

items.title: I can apply Ohm's law (V = IR) to solve circuit problems
items.what: Ohm's law states V = IR, which can be rearranged to I = V/R or R = V/I. This allows calculation of any quantity when the other two are known.
items.why: Ohm's law is the fundamental equation for circuit analysis, allowing prediction of how changing one quantity affects the others.
items.example: A 1000 Î© resistor is connected to a 9 V battery. The current is I = V/R = 9/1000 = 0.009 A = 9 mA. If the battery voltage doubles, the current also doubles to 18 mA.

items.title: I can interpret I-V characteristic graphs and identify ohmic and non-ohmic components
items.what: An I-V graph plots current against potential difference. Ohmic components show a straight line through the origin (constant resistance). Non-ohmic components show curved lines (varying resistance).
items.why: I-V graphs reveal how components behave across different conditions, which is crucial for selecting the right component for a specific application.
items.example: A resistor shows a straight I-V line with gradient 1/R. A light bulb shows a curve that bends over because its resistance increases as it heats up and the filament gets hotter.

items.title: I can calculate resistance from the gradient of an I-V graph
items.what: For an I-V graph with I on the y-axis and V on the x-axis, the gradient equals 1/R. Therefore R = 1/gradient = rise/run inverted to run/rise.
items.why: Graphical analysis of experimental data allows determination of resistance even when values fluctuate, by finding the best-fit line.
items.example: An I-V graph shows a straight line passing through (0,0) and (10 V, 2 A). The gradient is 2/10 = 0.2 A/V. Therefore R = 1/0.2 = 5 Î©.

items.title: I can describe and construct circuits to obtain I-V data experimentally
items.what: An I-V experiment uses a variable power supply, ammeter in series, and voltmeter in parallel with the test component. Measurements are taken at multiple voltage settings.
items.why: Experimental determination of I-V characteristics is essential for testing components and verifying theoretical predictions.
items.example: Connect a resistor to a variable power supply (0-12 V). Record current and voltage at 2 V intervals. Plot points on an I-V graph. A straight line through the origin confirms ohmic behaviour.
